author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: It was the fourth of February in the year 1875. It had been a severe winter, and the snow lay deep in the gorges of the Gilmerton Mountains. The steam ploughs had, however, kept the railroad open, and the evening train which connects the long line of coal-mining and iron-working settlements was slowly groaning its way up the steep gradients which lead from Stagville on the plain to Vermissa, the central township which lies at the head of Vermissa Valley.

next.content: From this point the track sweeps downward to Bartons Crossing, Helmdale, and the purely agricultural county of Merton. It was a single track railroad; but at every siding—and they were numerous—long lines of trucks piled with coal and iron ore told of the hidden wealth which had brought a rude population and a bustling life to this most desolate corner of the United States of America.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: From this point the track sweeps downward to Bartons Crossing, Helmdale, and the purely agricultural county of Merton. It was a single track railroad; but at every siding—and they were numerous—long lines of trucks piled with coal and iron ore told of the hidden wealth which had brought a rude population and a bustling life to this most desolate corner of the United States of America.

next.content: For desolate it was! Little could the first pioneer who had traversed it have ever imagined that the fairest prairies and the most lush water pastures were valueless compared to this gloomy land of black crag and tangled forest. Above the dark and often scarcely penetrable woods upon their flanks, the high, bare crowns of the mountains, white snow, and jagged rock towered upon each flank, leaving a long, winding, tortuous valley in the centre.

previous.content: It was the fourth of February in the year 1875. It had been a severe winter, and the snow lay deep in the gorges of the Gilmerton Mountains. The steam ploughs had, however, kept the railroad open, and the evening train which connects the long line of coal-mining and iron-working settlements was slowly groaning its way up the steep gradients which lead from Stagville on the plain to Vermissa, the central township which lies at the head of Vermissa Valley.

content: For desolate it was! Little could the first pioneer who had traversed it have ever imagined that the fairest prairies and the most lush water pastures were valueless compared to this gloomy land of black crag and tangled forest. Above the dark and often scarcely penetrable woods upon their flanks, the high, bare crowns of the mountains, white snow, and jagged rock towered upon each flank, leaving a long, winding, tortuous valley in the centre.

next.content: Up this the little train was slowly crawling.

previous.content: From this point the track sweeps downward to Bartons Crossing, Helmdale, and the purely agricultural county of Merton. It was a single track railroad; but at every siding—and they were numerous—long lines of trucks piled with coal and iron ore told of the hidden wealth which had brought a rude population and a bustling life to this most desolate corner of the United States of America.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: Up this the little train was slowly crawling.

next.content: The oil lamps had just been lit in the leading passenger car, a long, bare carriage in which some twenty or thirty people were seated. The greater number of these were workmen returning from their day's toil in the lower part of the valley. At least a dozen, by their grimed faces and the safety lanterns which they carried, proclaimed themselves miners.

previous.content: For desolate it was! Little could the first pioneer who had traversed it have ever imagined that the fairest prairies and the most lush water pastures were valueless compared to this gloomy land of black crag and tangled forest. Above the dark and often scarcely penetrable woods upon their flanks, the high, bare crowns of the mountains, white snow, and jagged rock towered upon each flank, leaving a long, winding, tortuous valley in the centre.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: The oil lamps had just been lit in the leading passenger car, a long, bare carriage in which some twenty or thirty people were seated. The greater number of these were workmen returning from their day's toil in the lower part of the valley. At least a dozen, by their grimed faces and the safety lanterns which they carried, proclaimed themselves miners.

next.content: These sat smoking in a group and conversed in low voices, glancing occasionally at two men on the opposite side of the car, whose uniforms and badges showed them to be policemen.

previous.content: Up this the little train was slowly crawling.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: These sat smoking in a group and conversed in low voices, glancing occasionally at two men on the opposite side of the car, whose uniforms and badges showed them to be policemen.

next.content: Several women of the labouring class and one or two travellers who might have been small local storekeepers made up the rest of the company, with the exception of one young man in a corner by himself. It is with this man that we are concerned. Take a good look at him; for he is worth it.

previous.content: The oil lamps had just been lit in the leading passenger car, a long, bare carriage in which some twenty or thirty people were seated. The greater number of these were workmen returning from their day's toil in the lower part of the valley. At least a dozen, by their grimed faces and the safety lanterns which they carried, proclaimed themselves miners.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: Several women of the labouring class and one or two travellers who might have been small local storekeepers made up the rest of the company, with the exception of one young man in a corner by himself. It is with this man that we are concerned. Take a good look at him; for he is worth it.

next.content: He is a fresh-complexioned, middle-sized young man, not far, one would guess, from his thirtieth year. He has large, shrewd, humorous gray eyes which twinkle inquiringly from time to time as he looks round through his spectacles at the people about him. It is easy to see that he is of a sociable and possibly simple disposition, anxious to be friendly to all men.

previous.content: These sat smoking in a group and conversed in low voices, glancing occasionally at two men on the opposite side of the car, whose uniforms and badges showed them to be policemen.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: He is a fresh-complexioned, middle-sized young man, not far, one would guess, from his thirtieth year. He has large, shrewd, humorous gray eyes which twinkle inquiringly from time to time as he looks round through his spectacles at the people about him. It is easy to see that he is of a sociable and possibly simple disposition, anxious to be friendly to all men.

next.content: Anyone could pick him at once as gregarious in his habits and communicative in his nature, with a quick wit and a ready smile. And yet the man who studied him more closely might discern a certain firmness of jaw and grim tightness about the lips which would warn him that there were depths beyond, and that this pleasant, brown-haired young Irishman might conceivably leave his mark for good or evil upon any society to which he was introduced.

previous.content: Several women of the labouring class and one or two travellers who might have been small local storekeepers made up the rest of the company, with the exception of one young man in a corner by himself. It is with this man that we are concerned. Take a good look at him; for he is worth it.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: Anyone could pick him at once as gregarious in his habits and communicative in his nature, with a quick wit and a ready smile. And yet the man who studied him more closely might discern a certain firmness of jaw and grim tightness about the lips which would warn him that there were depths beyond, and that this pleasant, brown-haired young Irishman might conceivably leave his mark for good or evil upon any society to which he was introduced.

next.content: Having made one or two tentative remarks to the nearest miner, and receiving only short, gruff replies, the traveller resigned himself to uncongenial silence, staring moodily out of the window at the fading landscape.

previous.content: He is a fresh-complexioned, middle-sized young man, not far, one would guess, from his thirtieth year. He has large, shrewd, humorous gray eyes which twinkle inquiringly from time to time as he looks round through his spectacles at the people about him. It is easy to see that he is of a sociable and possibly simple disposition, anxious to be friendly to all men.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: Having made one or two tentative remarks to the nearest miner, and receiving only short, gruff replies, the traveller resigned himself to uncongenial silence, staring moodily out of the window at the fading landscape.

next.content: It was not a cheering prospect. Through the growing gloom there pulsed the red glow of the furnaces on the sides of the hills. Great heaps of slag and dumps of cinders loomed up on each side, with the high shafts of the collieries towering above them. Huddled groups of mean, wooden houses, the windows of which were beginning to outline themselves in light, were scattered here and there along the line, and the frequent halting places were crowded with their swarthy inhabitants.

previous.content: Anyone could pick him at once as gregarious in his habits and communicative in his nature, with a quick wit and a ready smile. And yet the man who studied him more closely might discern a certain firmness of jaw and grim tightness about the lips which would warn him that there were depths beyond, and that this pleasant, brown-haired young Irishman might conceivably leave his mark for good or evil upon any society to which he was introduced.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: It was not a cheering prospect. Through the growing gloom there pulsed the red glow of the furnaces on the sides of the hills. Great heaps of slag and dumps of cinders loomed up on each side, with the high shafts of the collieries towering above them. Huddled groups of mean, wooden houses, the windows of which were beginning to outline themselves in light, were scattered here and there along the line, and the frequent halting places were crowded with their swarthy inhabitants.

next.content: The iron and coal valleys of the Vermissa district were no resorts for the leisured or the cultured. Everywhere there were stern signs of the crudest battle of life, the rude work to be done, and the rude, strong workers who did it.

previous.content: Having made one or two tentative remarks to the nearest miner, and receiving only short, gruff replies, the traveller resigned himself to uncongenial silence, staring moodily out of the window at the fading landscape.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: The iron and coal valleys of the Vermissa district were no resorts for the leisured or the cultured. Everywhere there were stern signs of the crudest battle of life, the rude work to be done, and the rude, strong workers who did it.

next.content: The young traveller gazed out into this dismal country with a face of mingled repulsion and interest, which showed that the scene was new to him. At intervals he drew from his pocket a bulky letter to which he referred, and on the margins of which he scribbled some notes. Once from the back of his waist he produced something which one would hardly have expected to find in the possession of so mild-mannered a man.

previous.content: It was not a cheering prospect. Through the growing gloom there pulsed the red glow of the furnaces on the sides of the hills. Great heaps of slag and dumps of cinders loomed up on each side, with the high shafts of the collieries towering above them. Huddled groups of mean, wooden houses, the windows of which were beginning to outline themselves in light, were scattered here and there along the line, and the frequent halting places were crowded with their swarthy inhabitants.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: The young traveller gazed out into this dismal country with a face of mingled repulsion and interest, which showed that the scene was new to him. At intervals he drew from his pocket a bulky letter to which he referred, and on the margins of which he scribbled some notes. Once from the back of his waist he produced something which one would hardly have expected to find in the possession of so mild-mannered a man.

next.content: It was a navy revolver of the largest size. As he turned it slantwise to the light, the glint upon the rims of the copper shells within the drum showed that it was fully loaded. He quickly restored it to his secret pocket, but not before it had been observed by a working man who had seated himself upon the adjoining bench.

previous.content: The iron and coal valleys of the Vermissa district were no resorts for the leisured or the cultured. Everywhere there were stern signs of the crudest battle of life, the rude work to be done, and the rude, strong workers who did it.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: It was a navy revolver of the largest size. As he turned it slantwise to the light, the glint upon the rims of the copper shells within the drum showed that it was fully loaded. He quickly restored it to his secret pocket, but not before it had been observed by a working man who had seated himself upon the adjoining bench.

next.content: "Hullo, mate!" said he. "You seem heeled and ready."

At intervals he drew from his pocket a bulky letter to which he referred, and on the margins of which he scribbled some notes. Once from the back of his waist he produced something which one would hardly have expected to find in the possession of so mild-mannered a man.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Hullo, mate!" said he. "You seem heeled and ready."

next.content: The young man smiled with an air of embarrassment.

previous.content: It was a navy revolver of the largest size. As he turned it slantwise to the light, the glint upon the rims of the copper shells within the drum showed that it was fully loaded. He quickly restored it to his secret pocket, but not before it had been observed by a working man who had seated himself upon the adjoining bench.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: The young man smiled with an air of embarrassment.

next.content: "Yes," said he, "we need them sometimes in the place I come from."

previous.content: "Hullo, mate!" said he. "You seem heeled and ready."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Yes," said he, "we need them sometimes in the place I come from."

next.content: "And where may that be?"

previous.content: The young man smiled with an air of embarrassment.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "And where may that be?"

next.content: "I'm last from Chicago."

previous.content: "Yes," said he, "we need them sometimes in the place I come from."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I'm last from Chicago."

next.content: "A stranger in these parts?"

previous.content: "And where may that be?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "A stranger in these parts?"

next.content: "Yes."

previous.content: "I'm last from Chicago."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Yes."

next.content: "You may find you need it here," said the workman.

previous.content: "A stranger in these parts?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "You may find you need it here," said the workman.

next.content: "Ah! is that so?" The young man seemed interested.

previous.content: "Yes."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Ah! is that so?" The young man seemed interested.

next.content: "Have you heard nothing of doings hereabouts?"

previous.content: "You may find you need it here," said the workman.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Have you heard nothing of doings hereabouts?"

next.content: "Nothing out of the way."

previous.content: "Ah! is that so?" The young man seemed interested.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Nothing out of the way."

next.content: "Why, I thought the country was full of it. You'll hear quick enough. What made you come here?"

previous.content: "Have you heard nothing of doings hereabouts?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Why, I thought the country was full of it. You'll hear quick enough. What made you come here?"

next.content: "I heard there was always work for a willing man."

previous.content: "Nothing out of the way."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I heard there was always work for a willing man."

next.content: "Are you a member of the union?"

previous.content: "Why, I thought the country was full of it. You'll hear quick enough. What made you come here?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Are you a member of the union?"

next.content: "Sure."

previous.content: "I heard there was always work for a willing man."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Sure."

next.content: "Then you'll get your job, I guess. Have you any friends?"

previous.content: "Are you a member of the union?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Then you'll get your job, I guess. Have you any friends?"

next.content: "Not yet; but I have the means of making them."

previous.content: "Sure."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Not yet; but I have the means of making them."

next.content: "How's that, then?"

previous.content: "Then you'll get your job, I guess. Have you any friends?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "How's that, then?"

next.content: "I am one of the Eminent Order of Freemen. There's no town without a lodge, and where there is a lodge I'll find my friends."

previous.content: "Not yet; but I have the means of making them."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I am one of the Eminent Order of Freemen. There's no town without a lodge, and where there is a lodge I'll find my friends."

next.content: The remark had a singular effect upon his companion. He glanced round suspiciously at the others in the car. The miners were still whispering among themselves. The two police officers were dozing. He came across, seated himself close to the young traveller, and held out his hand.

previous.content: "How's that, then?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: The remark had a singular effect upon his companion. He glanced round suspiciously at the others in the car. The miners were still whispering among themselves. The two police officers were dozing. He came across, seated himself close to the young traveller, and held out his hand.

next.content: "Put it there," he said.

previous.content: "I am one of the Eminent Order of Freemen. There's no town without a lodge, and where there is a lodge I'll find my friends."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Put it there," he said.

next.content: A hand-grip passed between the two.

previous.content: The remark had a singular effect upon his companion. He glanced round suspiciously at the others in the car. The miners were still whispering among themselves. The two police officers were dozing. He came across, seated himself close to the young traveller, and held out his hand.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: A hand-grip passed between the two.

next.content: "I see you speak the truth," said the workman. "But it's well to make certain." He raised his right hand to his right eyebrow. The traveller at once raised his left hand to his left eyebrow.

previous.content: "Put it there," he said.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I see you speak the truth," said the workman. "But it's well to make certain." He raised his right hand to his right eyebrow. The traveller at once raised his left hand to his left eyebrow.

next.content: "Dark nights are unpleasant," said the workman.

previous.content: A hand-grip passed between the two.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Dark nights are unpleasant," said the workman.

next.content: "Yes, for strangers to travel," the other answered.

previous.content: "I see you speak the truth," said the workman. "But it's well to make certain." He raised his right hand to his right eyebrow. The traveller at once raised his left hand to his left eyebrow.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Yes, for strangers to travel," the other answered.

next.content: "That's good enough. I'm Brother Scanlan, Lodge 341, Vermissa Valley. Glad to see you in these parts."

previous.content: "Dark nights are unpleasant," said the workman.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "That's good enough. I'm Brother Scanlan, Lodge 341, Vermissa Valley. Glad to see you in these parts."

next.content: "Thank you. I'm Brother John McMurdo, Lodge 29, Chicago. Bodymaster J.H. Scott. But I am in luck to meet a brother so early."

previous.content: "Yes, for strangers to travel," the other answered.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Thank you. I'm Brother John McMurdo, Lodge 29, Chicago. Bodymaster J.H. Scott. But I am in luck to meet a brother so early."

next.content: "Well, there are plenty of us about. You won't find the order more flourishing anywhere in the States than right here in Vermissa Valley. But we could do with some lads like you. I can't understand a spry man of the union finding no work to do in Chicago."

previous.content: "That's good enough. I'm Brother Scanlan, Lodge 341, Vermissa Valley. Glad to see you in these parts."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Well, there are plenty of us about. You won't find the order more flourishing anywhere in the States than right here in Vermissa Valley. But we could do with some lads like you. I can't understand a spry man of the union finding no work to do in Chicago."

next.content: "I found plenty of work to do," said McMurdo.

previous.content: "Thank you. I'm Brother John McMurdo, Lodge 29, Chicago. Bodymaster J.H. Scott. But I am in luck to meet a brother so early."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I found plenty of work to do," said McMurdo.

next.content: "Then why did you leave?"

previous.content: "Well, there are plenty of us about. You won't find the order more flourishing anywhere in the States than right here in Vermissa Valley. But we could do with some lads like you. I can't understand a spry man of the union finding no work to do in Chicago."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Then why did you leave?"

next.content: McMurdo nodded towards the policemen and smiled. "I guess those chaps would be glad to know," he said.

previous.content: "I found plenty of work to do," said McMurdo.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: McMurdo nodded towards the policemen and smiled. "I guess those chaps would be glad to know," he said.

next.content: Scanlan groaned sympathetically. "In trouble?" he asked in a whisper.

previous.content: "Then why did you leave?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: Scanlan groaned sympathetically. "In trouble?" he asked in a whisper.

next.content: "Deep."

previous.content: McMurdo nodded towards the policemen and smiled. "I guess those chaps would be glad to know," he said.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Deep."

next.content: "A penitentiary job?"

previous.content: Scanlan groaned sympathetically. "In trouble?" he asked in a whisper.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "A penitentiary job?"

next.content: "And the rest."

previous.content: "Deep."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "And the rest."

next.content: "Not a killing!"

previous.content: "A penitentiary job?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Not a killing!"

next.content: "It's early days to talk of such things," said McMurdo with the air of a man who had been surprised into saying more than he intended. "I've my own good reasons for leaving Chicago, and let that be enough for you. Who are you that you should take it on yourself to ask such things?" His gray eyes gleamed with sudden and dangerous anger from behind his glasses.

previous.content: "And the rest."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "It's early days to talk of such things," said McMurdo with the air of a man who had been surprised into saying more than he intended. "I've my own good reasons for leaving Chicago, and let that be enough for you. Who are you that you should take it on yourself to ask such things?" His gray eyes gleamed with sudden and dangerous anger from behind his glasses.

next.content: "All right, mate, no offense meant. The boys will think none the worse of you, whatever you may have done. Where are you bound for now?"

previous.content: "Not a killing!"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "All right, mate, no offense meant. The boys will think none the worse of you, whatever you may have done. Where are you bound for now?"

next.content: "Vermissa."

previous.content: "It's early days to talk of such things," said McMurdo with the air of a man who had been surprised into saying more than he intended. "I've my own good reasons for leaving Chicago, and let that be enough for you. Who are you that you should take it on yourself to ask such things?" His gray eyes gleamed with sudden and dangerous anger from behind his glasses.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Vermissa."

next.content: "That's the third halt down the line. Where are you staying?"

previous.content: "All right, mate, no offense meant. The boys will think none the worse of you, whatever you may have done. Where are you bound for now?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "That's the third halt down the line. Where are you staying?"

next.content: McMurdo took out an envelope and held it close to the murky oil lamp. "Here is the address—Jacob Shafter, Sheridan Street. It's a boarding house that was recommended by a man I knew in Chicago."

previous.content: "Vermissa."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: McMurdo took out an envelope and held it close to the murky oil lamp. "Here is the address—Jacob Shafter, Sheridan Street. It's a boarding house that was recommended by a man I knew in Chicago."

next.content: "Well, I don't know it; but Vermissa is out of my beat. I live at Hobson's Patch, and that's here where we are drawing up. But, say, there's one bit of advice I'll give you before we part: If you're in trouble in Vermissa, go straight to the Union House and see Boss McGinty. He is the Bodymaster of Vermissa Lodge, and nothing can happen in these parts unless Black Jack McGinty wants it.

previous.content: "That's the third halt down the line. Where are you staying?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Well, I don't know it; but Vermissa is out of my beat. I live at Hobson's Patch, and that's here where we are drawing up. But, say, there's one bit of advice I'll give you before we part: If you're in trouble in Vermissa, go straight to the Union House and see Boss McGinty. He is the Bodymaster of Vermissa Lodge, and nothing can happen in these parts unless Black Jack McGinty wants it.

next.content: So long, mate! Maybe we'll meet in lodge one of these evenings. But mind my words: If you are in trouble, go to Boss McGinty."

previous.content: McMurdo took out an envelope and held it close to the murky oil lamp. "Here is the address—Jacob Shafter, Sheridan Street. It's a boarding house that was recommended by a man I knew in Chicago."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: So long, mate! Maybe we'll meet in lodge one of these evenings. But mind my words: If you are in trouble, go to Boss McGinty."

next.content: Scanlan descended, and McMurdo was left once again to his thoughts. Night had now fallen, and the flames of the frequent furnaces were roaring and leaping in the darkness. Against their lurid background dark figures were bending and straining, twisting and turning, with the motion of winch or of windlass, to the rhythm of an eternal clank and roar.

previous.content: "Well, I don't know it; but Vermissa is out of my beat. I live at Hobson's Patch, and that's here where we are drawing up. But, say, there's one bit of advice I'll give you before we part: If you're in trouble in Vermissa, go straight to the Union House and see Boss McGinty. He is the Bodymaster of Vermissa Lodge, and nothing can happen in these parts unless Black Jack McGinty wants it.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: Scanlan descended, and McMurdo was left once again to his thoughts. Night had now fallen, and the flames of the frequent furnaces were roaring and leaping in the darkness. Against their lurid background dark figures were bending and straining, twisting and turning, with the motion of winch or of windlass, to the rhythm of an eternal clank and roar.

next.content: "I guess hell must look something like that," said a voice.

previous.content: So long, mate! Maybe we'll meet in lodge one of these evenings. But mind my words: If you are in trouble, go to Boss McGinty."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I guess hell must look something like that," said a voice.

next.content: McMurdo turned and saw that one of the policemen had shifted in his seat and was staring out into the fiery waste.

previous.content: Scanlan descended, and McMurdo was left once again to his thoughts. Night had now fallen, and the flames of the frequent furnaces were roaring and leaping in the darkness. Against their lurid background dark figures were bending and straining, twisting and turning, with the motion of winch or of windlass, to the rhythm of an eternal clank and roar.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: McMurdo turned and saw that one of the policemen had shifted in his seat and was staring out into the fiery waste.

next.content: "For that matter," said the other policeman, "I allow that hell must BE something like that. If there are worse devils down yonder than some we could name, it's more than I'd expect. I guess you are new to this part, young man?"

previous.content: "I guess hell must look something like that," said a voice.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "For that matter," said the other policeman, "I allow that hell must BE something like that. If there are worse devils down yonder than some we could name, it's more than I'd expect. I guess you are new to this part, young man?"

next.content: "Well, what if I am?" McMurdo answered in a surly voice.

previous.content: McMurdo turned and saw that one of the policemen had shifted in his seat and was staring out into the fiery waste.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Well, what if I am?" McMurdo answered in a surly voice.

next.content: "Just this, mister, that I should advise you to be careful in choosing your friends. I don't think I'd begin with Mike Scanlan or his gang if I were you."

previous.content: "For that matter," said the other policeman, "I allow that hell must BE something like that. If there are worse devils down yonder than some we could name, it's more than I'd expect. I guess you are new to this part, young man?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Just this, mister, that I should advise you to be careful in choosing your friends. I don't think I'd begin with Mike Scanlan or his gang if I were you."

next.content: "What the hell is it to you who are my friends?" roared McMurdo in a voice which brought every head in the carriage round to witness the altercation. "Did I ask you for your advice, or did you think me such a sucker that I couldn't move without it? You speak when you are spoken to, and by the Lord you'd have to wait a long time if it was me!" He thrust out his face and grinned at the patrolmen like a snarling dog.

previous.content: "Well, what if I am?" McMurdo answered in a surly voice.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "What the hell is it to you who are my friends?" roared McMurdo in a voice which brought every head in the carriage round to witness the altercation. "Did I ask you for your advice, or did you think me such a sucker that I couldn't move without it? You speak when you are spoken to, and by the Lord you'd have to wait a long time if it was me!" He thrust out his face and grinned at the patrolmen like a snarling dog.

next.content: The two policemen, heavy, good-natured men, were taken aback by the extraordinary vehemence with which their friendly advances had been rejected.

previous.content: "Just this, mister, that I should advise you to be careful in choosing your friends. I don't think I'd begin with Mike Scanlan or his gang if I were you."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: The two policemen, heavy, good-natured men, were taken aback by the extraordinary vehemence with which their friendly advances had been rejected.

next.content: "No offense, stranger," said one. "It was a warning for your own good, seeing that you are, by your own showing, new to the place."

previous.content: "What the hell is it to you who are my friends?" roared McMurdo in a voice which brought every head in the carriage round to witness the altercation. "Did I ask you for your advice, or did you think me such a sucker that I couldn't move without it? You speak when you are spoken to, and by the Lord you'd have to wait a long time if it was me!" He thrust out his face and grinned at the patrolmen like a snarling dog.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "No offense, stranger," said one. "It was a warning for your own good, seeing that you are, by your own showing, new to the place."

next.content: "I'm new to the place; but I'm not new to you and your kind!" cried McMurdo in cold fury. "I guess you're the same in all places, shoving your advice in when nobody asks for it."

previous.content: The two policemen, heavy, good-natured men, were taken aback by the extraordinary vehemence with which their friendly advances had been rejected.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I'm new to the place; but I'm not new to you and your kind!" cried McMurdo in cold fury. "I guess you're the same in all places, shoving your advice in when nobody asks for it."

next.content: "Maybe we'll see more of you before very long," said one of the patrolmen with a grin. "You're a real hand-picked one, if I am a judge."

previous.content: "No offense, stranger," said one. "It was a warning for your own good, seeing that you are, by your own showing, new to the place."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Maybe we'll see more of you before very long," said one of the patrolmen with a grin. "You're a real hand-picked one, if I am a judge."

next.content: "I was thinking the same," remarked the other. "I guess we may meet again."

previous.content: "I'm new to the place; but I'm not new to you and your kind!" cried McMurdo in cold fury. "I guess you're the same in all places, shoving your advice in when nobody asks for it."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I was thinking the same," remarked the other. "I guess we may meet again."

next.content: "I'm not afraid of you, and don't you think it!" cried McMurdo. "My name's Jack McMurdo—see? If you want me, you'll find me at Jacob Shafter's on Sheridan Street, Vermissa; so I'm not hiding from you, am I? Day or night I dare to look the like of you in the face—don't make any mistake about that!"

previous.content: "Maybe we'll see more of you before very long," said one of the patrolmen with a grin. "You're a real hand-picked one, if I am a judge."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I'm not afraid of you, and don't you think it!" cried McMurdo. "My name's Jack McMurdo—see? If you want me, you'll find me at Jacob Shafter's on Sheridan Street, Vermissa; so I'm not hiding from you, am I? Day or night I dare to look the like of you in the face—don't make any mistake about that!"

next.content: There was a murmur of sympathy and admiration from the miners at the dauntless demeanour of the newcomer, while the two policemen shrugged their shoulders and renewed a conversation between themselves.

previous.content: "I was thinking the same," remarked the other. "I guess we may meet again."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: There was a murmur of sympathy and admiration from the miners at the dauntless demeanour of the newcomer, while the two policemen shrugged their shoulders and renewed a conversation between themselves.

next.content: A few minutes later the train ran into the ill-lit station, and there was a general clearing; for Vermissa was by far the largest town on the line. McMurdo picked up his leather gripsack and was about to start off into the darkness, when one of the miners accosted him.

previous.content: "I'm not afraid of you, and don't you think it!" cried McMurdo. "My name's Jack McMurdo—see? If you want me, you'll find me at Jacob Shafter's on Sheridan Street, Vermissa; so I'm not hiding from you, am I? Day or night I dare to look the like of you in the face—don't make any mistake about that!"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: A few minutes later the train ran into the ill-lit station, and there was a general clearing; for Vermissa was by far the largest town on the line. McMurdo picked up his leather gripsack and was about to start off into the darkness, when one of the miners accosted him.

next.content: "By Gar, mate! you know how to speak to the cops," he said in a voice of awe. "It was grand to hear you. Let me carry your grip and show you the road. I'm passing Shafter's on the way to my own shack."

previous.content: There was a murmur of sympathy and admiration from the miners at the dauntless demeanour of the newcomer, while the two policemen shrugged their shoulders and renewed a conversation between themselves.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "By Gar, mate! you know how to speak to the cops," he said in a voice of awe. "It was grand to hear you. Let me carry your grip and show you the road. I'm passing Shafter's on the way to my own shack."

next.content: There was a chorus of friendly "Good-nights" from the other miners as they passed from the platform. Before ever he had set foot in it, McMurdo the turbulent had become a character in Vermissa.

previous.content: A few minutes later the train ran into the ill-lit station, and there was a general clearing; for Vermissa was by far the largest town on the line. McMurdo picked up his leather gripsack and was about to start off into the darkness, when one of the miners accosted him.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: There was a chorus of friendly "Good-nights" from the other miners as they passed from the platform. Before ever he had set foot in it, McMurdo the turbulent had become a character in Vermissa.

next.content: The country had been a place of terror; but the town was in its way even more depressing. Down that long valley there was at least a certain gloomy grandeur in the huge fires and the clouds of drifting smoke, while the strength and industry of man found fitting monuments in the hills which he had spilled by the side of his monstrous excavations.

previous.content: "By Gar, mate! you know how to speak to the cops," he said in a voice of awe. "It was grand to hear you. Let me carry your grip and show you the road. I'm passing Shafter's on the way to my own shack."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: The country had been a place of terror; but the town was in its way even more depressing. Down that long valley there was at least a certain gloomy grandeur in the huge fires and the clouds of drifting smoke, while the strength and industry of man found fitting monuments in the hills which he had spilled by the side of his monstrous excavations.

next.content: But the town showed a dead level of mean ugliness and squalor. The broad street was churned up by the traffic into a horrible rutted paste of muddy snow. The sidewalks were narrow and uneven. The numerous gas-lamps served only to show more clearly a long line of wooden houses, each with its veranda facing the street, unkempt and dirty.

previous.content: There was a chorus of friendly "Good-nights" from the other miners as they passed from the platform. Before ever he had set foot in it, McMurdo the turbulent had become a character in Vermissa.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: But the town showed a dead level of mean ugliness and squalor. The broad street was churned up by the traffic into a horrible rutted paste of muddy snow. The sidewalks were narrow and uneven. The numerous gas-lamps served only to show more clearly a long line of wooden houses, each with its veranda facing the street, unkempt and dirty.

next.content: As they approached the centre of the town the scene was brightened by a row of well-lit stores, and even more by a cluster of saloons and gaming houses, in which the miners spent their hard-earned but generous wages.

previous.content: The country had been a place of terror; but the town was in its way even more depressing. Down that long valley there was at least a certain gloomy grandeur in the huge fires and the clouds of drifting smoke, while the strength and industry of man found fitting monuments in the hills which he had spilled by the side of his monstrous excavations.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: As they approached the centre of the town the scene was brightened by a row of well-lit stores, and even more by a cluster of saloons and gaming houses, in which the miners spent their hard-earned but generous wages.

next.content: "That's the Union House," said the guide, pointing to one saloon which rose almost to the dignity of being a hotel. "Jack McGinty is the boss there."

previous.content: But the town showed a dead level of mean ugliness and squalor. The broad street was churned up by the traffic into a horrible rutted paste of muddy snow. The sidewalks were narrow and uneven. The numerous gas-lamps served only to show more clearly a long line of wooden houses, each with its veranda facing the street, unkempt and dirty.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "That's the Union House," said the guide, pointing to one saloon which rose almost to the dignity of being a hotel. "Jack McGinty is the boss there."

next.content: "What sort of a man is he?" McMurdo asked.

previous.content: As they approached the centre of the town the scene was brightened by a row of well-lit stores, and even more by a cluster of saloons and gaming houses, in which the miners spent their hard-earned but generous wages.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "What sort of a man is he?" McMurdo asked.

next.content: "What! have you never heard of the boss?"

previous.content: "That's the Union House," said the guide, pointing to one saloon which rose almost to the dignity of being a hotel. "Jack McGinty is the boss there."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "What! have you never heard of the boss?"

next.content: "How could I have heard of him when you know that I am a stranger in these parts?"

previous.content: "What sort of a man is he?" McMurdo asked.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "How could I have heard of him when you know that I am a stranger in these parts?"

next.content: "Well, I thought his name was known clear across the country. It's been in the papers often enough."

previous.content: "What! have you never heard of the boss?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Well, I thought his name was known clear across the country. It's been in the papers often enough."

next.content: "What for?"

previous.content: "How could I have heard of him when you know that I am a stranger in these parts?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "What for?"

next.content: "Well," the miner lowered his voice—"over the affairs."

previous.content: "Well, I thought his name was known clear across the country. It's been in the papers often enough."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Well," the miner lowered his voice—"over the affairs."

next.content: "What affairs?"

previous.content: "What for?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "What affairs?"

next.content: "Good Lord, mister! you are queer, if I must say it without offense. There's only one set of affairs that you'll hear of in these parts, and that's the affairs of the Scowrers."

previous.content: "Well," the miner lowered his voice—"over the affairs."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Good Lord, mister! you are queer, if I must say it without offense. There's only one set of affairs that you'll hear of in these parts, and that's the affairs of the Scowrers."

next.content: "Why, I seem to have read of the Scowrers in Chicago. A gang of murderers, are they not?"

previous.content: "What affairs?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Why, I seem to have read of the Scowrers in Chicago. A gang of murderers, are they not?"

next.content: "Hush, on your life!" cried the miner, standing still in alarm, and gazing in amazement at his companion. "Man, you won't live long in these parts if you speak in the open street like that. Many a man has had the life beaten out of him for less."

previous.content: "Good Lord, mister! you are queer, if I must say it without offense. There's only one set of affairs that you'll hear of in these parts, and that's the affairs of the Scowrers."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Hush, on your life!" cried the miner, standing still in alarm, and gazing in amazement at his companion. "Man, you won't live long in these parts if you speak in the open street like that. Many a man has had the life beaten out of him for less."

next.content: "Well, I know nothing about them. It's only what I have read."

previous.content: "Why, I seem to have read of the Scowrers in Chicago. A gang of murderers, are they not?"

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Well, I know nothing about them. It's only what I have read."

next.content: "And I'm not saying that you have not read the truth." The man looked nervously round him as he spoke, peering into the shadows as if he feared to see some lurking danger. "If killing is murder, then God knows there is murder and to spare. But don't you dare to breathe the name of Jack McGinty in connection with it, stranger; for every whisper goes back to him, and he is not one that is likely to let it pass.

previous.content: "Hush, on your life!" cried the miner, standing still in alarm, and gazing in amazement at his companion. "Man, you won't live long in these parts if you speak in the open street like that. Many a man has had the life beaten out of him for less."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "And I'm not saying that you have not read the truth." The man looked nervously round him as he spoke, peering into the shadows as if he feared to see some lurking danger. "If killing is murder, then God knows there is murder and to spare. But don't you dare to breathe the name of Jack McGinty in connection with it, stranger; for every whisper goes back to him, and he is not one that is likely to let it pass.

next.content: Now, that's the house you're after, that one standing back from the street. You'll find old Jacob Shafter that runs it as honest a man as lives in this township."

previous.content: "Well, I know nothing about them. It's only what I have read."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: Now, that's the house you're after, that one standing back from the street. You'll find old Jacob Shafter that runs it as honest a man as lives in this township."

next.content: "I thank you," said McMurdo, and shaking hands with his new acquaintance he plodded, gripsack in hand, up the path which led to the dwelling house, at the door of which he gave a resounding knock.

previous.content: "And I'm not saying that you have not read the truth." The man looked nervously round him as he spoke, peering into the shadows as if he feared to see some lurking danger. "If killing is murder, then God knows there is murder and to spare. But don't you dare to breathe the name of Jack McGinty in connection with it, stranger; for every whisper goes back to him, and he is not one that is likely to let it pass.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I thank you," said McMurdo, and shaking hands with his new acquaintance he plodded, gripsack in hand, up the path which led to the dwelling house, at the door of which he gave a resounding knock.

next.content: It was opened at once by someone very different from what he had expected. It was a woman, young and singularly beautiful. She was of the German type, blonde and fair-haired, with the piquant contrast of a pair of beautiful dark eyes with which she surveyed the stranger with surprise and a pleasing embarrassment which brought a wave of colour over her pale face.

previous.content: Now, that's the house you're after, that one standing back from the street. You'll find old Jacob Shafter that runs it as honest a man as lives in this township."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: It was opened at once by someone very different from what he had expected. It was a woman, young and singularly beautiful. She was of the German type, blonde and fair-haired, with the piquant contrast of a pair of beautiful dark eyes with which she surveyed the stranger with surprise and a pleasing embarrassment which brought a wave of colour over her pale face.

next.content: Framed in the bright light of the open doorway, it seemed to McMurdo that he had never seen a more beautiful picture; the more attractive for its contrast with the sordid and gloomy surroundings. A lovely violet growing upon one of those black slag-heaps of the mines would not have seemed more surprising.

previous.content: "I thank you," said McMurdo, and shaking hands with his new acquaintance he plodded, gripsack in hand, up the path which led to the dwelling house, at the door of which he gave a resounding knock.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: Framed in the bright light of the open doorway, it seemed to McMurdo that he had never seen a more beautiful picture; the more attractive for its contrast with the sordid and gloomy surroundings. A lovely violet growing upon one of those black slag-heaps of the mines would not have seemed more surprising.

next.content: So entranced was he that he stood staring without a word, and it was she who broke the silence.

previous.content: It was opened at once by someone very different from what he had expected. It was a woman, young and singularly beautiful. She was of the German type, blonde and fair-haired, with the piquant contrast of a pair of beautiful dark eyes with which she surveyed the stranger with surprise and a pleasing embarrassment which brought a wave of colour over her pale face.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: So entranced was he that he stood staring without a word, and it was she who broke the silence.

next.content: "I thought it was father," said she with a pleasing little touch of a German accent. "Did you come to see him? He is down town. I expect him back every minute."

previous.content: Framed in the bright light of the open doorway, it seemed to McMurdo that he had never seen a more beautiful picture; the more attractive for its contrast with the sordid and gloomy surroundings. A lovely violet growing upon one of those black slag-heaps of the mines would not have seemed more surprising.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "I thought it was father," said she with a pleasing little touch of a German accent. "Did you come to see him? He is down town. I expect him back every minute."

next.content: McMurdo continued to gaze at her in open admiration until her eyes dropped in confusion before this masterful visitor.

previous.content: So entranced was he that he stood staring without a word, and it was she who broke the silence.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: McMurdo continued to gaze at her in open admiration until her eyes dropped in confusion before this masterful visitor.

next.content: "No, miss," he said at last, "I'm in no hurry to see him. But your house was recommended to me for board. I thought it might suit me—and now I know it will."

previous.content: "I thought it was father," said she with a pleasing little touch of a German accent. "Did you come to see him? He is down town. I expect him back every minute."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "No, miss," he said at last, "I'm in no hurry to see him. But your house was recommended to me for board. I thought it might suit me—and now I know it will."

next.content: "You are quick to make up your mind," said she with a smile.

previous.content: McMurdo continued to gaze at her in open admiration until her eyes dropped in confusion before this masterful visitor.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "You are quick to make up your mind," said she with a smile.

next.content: "Anyone but a blind man could do as much," the other answered.

previous.content: "No, miss," he said at last, "I'm in no hurry to see him. But your house was recommended to me for board. I thought it might suit me—and now I know it will."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: "Anyone but a blind man could do as much," the other answered.

next.content: She laughed at the compliment. "Come right in, sir," she said. "I'm Miss Ettie Shafter, Mr. Shafter's daughter. My mother's dead, and I run the house. You can sit down by the stove in the front room until father comes along—Ah, here he is! So you can fix things with him right away."

previous.content: "You are quick to make up your mind," said she with a smile.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: She laughed at the compliment. "Come right in, sir," she said. "I'm Miss Ettie Shafter, Mr. Shafter's daughter. My mother's dead, and I run the house. You can sit down by the stove in the front room until father comes along—Ah, here he is! So you can fix things with him right away."

next.content: A heavy, elderly man came plodding up the path. In a few words McMurdo explained his business. A man of the name of Murphy had given him the address in Chicago. He in turn had had it from someone else. Old Shafter was quite ready. The stranger made no bones about terms, agreed at once to every condition, and was apparently fairly flush of money.

previous.content: "Anyone but a blind man could do as much," the other answered.

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: A heavy, elderly man came plodding up the path. In a few words McMurdo explained his business. A man of the name of Murphy had given him the address in Chicago. He in turn had had it from someone else. Old Shafter was quite ready. The stranger made no bones about terms, agreed at once to every condition, and was apparently fairly flush of money.

next.content: For seven dollars a week paid in advance he was to have board and lodging.

previous.content: She laughed at the compliment. "Come right in, sir," she said. "I'm Miss Ettie Shafter, Mr. Shafter's daughter. My mother's dead, and I run the house. You can sit down by the stove in the front room until father comes along—Ah, here he is! So you can fix things with him right away."

author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
content: For seven dollars a week paid in advance he was to have board and lodging.

next.content: So it was that McMurdo, the self-confessed fugitive from justice, took up his abode under the roof of the Shafters, the first step which was to lead to so long and dark a train of events, ending in a far distant land.

previous.content: A heavy, elderly man came plodding up the path. In a few words McMurdo explained his business. A man of the name of Murphy had given him the address in Chicago. He in turn had had it from someone else. Old Shafter was quite ready. The stranger made no bones about terms, agreed at once to every condition, and was apparently fairly flush of money.

content: So it was that McMurdo, the self-confessed fugitive from justice, took up his abode under the roof of the Shafters, the first step which was to lead to so long and dark a train of events, ending in a far distant land.

previous.content: For seven dollars a week paid in advance he was to have board and lodging.
